meta.author: Leana Le
meta.purpose: Portfolio case studies with prototype-aware content
meta.notes: All projects are student projects. No fabricated metrics. Prototypes appear after their referenced sections.

case_studies.title: ProLog
case_studies.subtitle: A journey companion for neurodivergent apprentices
case_studies.summary: A centralized apprenticeship companion helping neurodivergent apprentices track progress, reduce cognitive overload, and build confidence through clear visualization and structured tools.
case_studies.context: School project in collaboration with ConnectHER at BCIT

hook.content:
Apprenticeship can take over 6,000 hours. That's years of work, spread across job sites, classrooms, and bureaucratic systems—often without a clear sense of whether you're on track.

Early in our research, we kept hearing the same thing: confusion was pushing people out. Not inability. Not lack of motivation. Just confusion about where they stood and what came next.

We wanted to build something that answered one question clearly: Where am I right now?

problem_framing.content:
Apprentices in British Columbia navigate a surprisingly fragmented system. Hours are logged in one place, competencies tracked in another, and certification requirements buried in dense PDFs.

For neurotypical users, this is frustrating. For neurodivergent apprentices—who may already struggle with executive function, time blindness, or information overload—it becomes a genuine barrier to completion.

The system wasn't designed to be hostile. It just wasn't designed with these users in mind.

methods: Persona development based on lived experience
Team reflection sessions (our team included neurodivergent members)
key_findings: Progress tracking is scattered across multiple platforms with no single source of truth
Official systems are desktop-first and difficult to use on job sites
Discrepancies between employer-logged and self-logged hours create anxiety
Neurodivergent users experience amplified cognitive load from inconsistent interfaces
research_process.reflection: We didn't have access to a large participant pool, so we leaned into what we did have: our own team's lived experience, publicly available documentation, and honest conversations with stakeholders. This shaped a more empathetic, if narrower, understanding of the problem.

early_challenges.content:
This project started too big.

We wanted to fix financial stress, employer communication, exam preparation, and progress tracking—all at once. Our advisor encouraged broad exploration, which felt productive at first but eventually led to paralysis.

It wasn't until we accepted that we couldn't solve everything that the project started moving. Narrowing our focus to neurodivergent apprentices gave us permission to go deeper instead of wider.

pivots.reason: A narrower scope allowed us to design with real empathy instead of generic assumptions. We could make decisions based on specific needs rather than trying to please everyone.

removedFeatures: Financial planning tools and budget calculators
pivot.reflection: Cutting these features wasn't giving up—it was choosing depth over breadth. Each one was a good idea on its own, but together they diluted the product into something generic.

weightLifted.title: From 6 problem spaces to 1 clear focus
weightLifted.caption: Every feature we removed made space for the ones that actually mattered. Depth over breadth turned a generic tool into something personal.

lofi_phase.content:
Our early sketches were deliberately rough. We weren't trying to make things look good—we were trying to understand what information mattered most and how quickly someone could find it.

The dashboard concept emerged early. We kept asking ourselves: if an apprentice opens this app on a break, what should they see in the first three seconds?

Progress bars, hour counts, and next-step prompts became the core. Everything else was secondary.

hifi_phase.content:
The high-fidelity designs prioritized calm. We chose soft colors, generous spacing, and typography that wouldn't feel clinical or overwhelming.

The dashboard became the emotional center of the app. Instead of hiding progress behind menus, we made it the first thing users see. Hours completed, hours remaining, competencies achieved—all visible at a glance.

Try scrolling through the dashboard below. Notice how the most important information stays anchored at the top, while details reveal themselves as you explore.

images.caption: The dashboard provides immediate progress visibility

prototype.description: Explore the dashboard experience. Pay attention to how progress is communicated without requiring any taps.

development.content:
As the developer on this project, I had to keep myself honest. It's easy to design features that sound impressive but would require complex backend infrastructure we couldn't build.

Data syncing with official systems? Not feasible without partnerships we didn't have. AI-generated quizzes? Possible, but only if we scoped them carefully.

Every feature was evaluated against a simple question: can we actually build this responsibly?
technical_decisions: Chose React Native for cross-platform efficiency
Designed offline-first architecture for job site use
Scoped AI features to avoid overpromising
constraints: No access to official SkilledTradesBC APIs
Team learning curve with mobile development

feature_breakdown.intro: Each feature was designed to reduce one specific point of friction. Click through the prototype below to see how they work together.

features.title: Progress Dashboard
features.description: A centralized view of hours completed, hours remaining, competencies achieved, and certification progress. No digging required—the answer to 'where am I?' is always visible.
features.why: Apprentices told us they often felt lost in their journey. The dashboard acts as a GPS, providing constant orientation.

features.title: Hours Discrepancy Detector
features.description: Compares user-logged hours against official records and flags mismatches. Users can document discrepancies and generate reports for their employers.
features.why: Hour discrepancies are stressful and common. Rather than fixing the problem, we gave users tools to advocate for themselves.

features.title: Financial Resources Hub
features.description: Links to grants, funding programs, and itemized cost breakdowns for apprenticeship expenses.
features.why: Financial stress came up repeatedly in research. We couldn't solve it, but we could make information easier to find.

features.title: AI Practice Quizzes
features.description: Generates unique practice questions based on trade competencies. Designed to build confidence before official exams.
features.why: Many apprentices feel unprepared for certification exams. Low-stakes practice helps reduce that anxiety.

prototype.description: Walk through each feature. Start with the dashboard, then explore the hours tracker and quiz flow.

validation.content:
We tested the prototype with a small group and heard something we didn't expect: relief.

Users described the dashboard as a 'GPS for my apprenticeship.' They appreciated that they didn't have to hunt for information—it was just there.

The hours tracker resonated especially strongly. One participant said they'd never realized they could document discrepancies themselves.

These weren't metrics we could quantify, but they felt meaningful.

key_quotes.quote: It's like a GPS for my apprenticeship.
I never realized I could document discrepancies myself.

outcomes: Users reported feeling relieved by progress visibility
Hours tracker addressed a previously unmet need

what_i_learned.reflection: When users said they felt 'relieved,' they were responding to design decisions—not just information architecture.

what_i_learned.insight: Scope control is a design skill
what_i_learned.reflection: Saying no to good ideas was harder than coming up with them.
Seeing how far you've come matters as much as knowing what's next.
In student work, we don't always have access to large sample sizes. That doesn't make insights less real.

next_steps.item: Pursue data partnerships with SkilledTradesBC to enable real-time syncing
Expand accessibility features including screen reader optimization and high-contrast modes
Develop offline-friendly experiences for use on job sites with limited connectivity

final_experience.intro:
The prototype below represents the complete flow we envisioned—from opening the app to checking progress, logging hours, and preparing for exams.

As you explore, notice how each screen tries to answer a question before you have to ask it.

prototype.description: Click through the full experience. Start from the dashboard and follow the natural flow.

case_studies.title: InkLink
case_studies.subtitle: Breaking writer's block through collaboration
case_studies.summary: A chain-writing platform that reduces writer's block by turning writing into a shared, low-pressure activity where users contribute one passage at a time.
responsibilities: Led user research and concept validation

hook.content:
Everyone has a story they never finished.

Maybe it's a novel that stalled at chapter three. Maybe it's a screenplay that never made it past the outline. The ideas were there—the momentum wasn't.

InkLink started with a simple question: what if writing didn't have to be a solo activity? What if the pressure of finishing was replaced by the fun of contributing?

problem_framing.content:
Writer's block isn't usually about running out of ideas. It's about pressure.

The blank page. The expectation of perfection. The lonely weight of being solely responsible for what comes next.

We wanted to design an experience that removed those barriers—not by making writing easier, but by making it shared.

methods: Peer surveys with amateur and hobbyist writers
Concept validation sessions to gauge interest
key_findings: Most creative writing happens on desktop or tablet—not mobile phones
Dense, text-heavy layouts discourage reading and contribution
New concepts require gentle onboarding; users won't explore without guidance
research_process.reflection: Our initial assumption was that mobile-first would work. Research quickly proved us wrong. Writers wanted screen real estate. They wanted to see the story unfold.

pivots.reason: Writers consistently preferred larger screens. Mobile felt cramped for both reading and contributing.
The newspaper aesthetic looked interesting but hurt readability. Hierarchy got lost in the visual noise.

pivots.from: Feature-heavy homepage with multiple entry points
pivots.reason: Users were overwhelmed by options. One clear path reduced hesitation.

removedFeatures: Multiple homepage entry points and discovery filters
pivot.reflection: Every feature we removed made the core experience stronger. InkLink became better by doing less.

weightLifted.title: From a feature-heavy homepage to a single clear action
weightLifted.caption: The homepage had six ways to start. Users chose none. One clear call-to-action made them choose every time.

lofi_phase.content:
Our lo-fi work focused on one core interaction: contributing to a story.

We sketched different approaches to showing story history, handling turn-taking, and branching narratives. The visuals were intentionally basic—we needed to test logic, not aesthetics.

What emerged was a simple chain: read what came before, add your piece, pass it on.

images.caption: Early exploration of the contribution flow

hifi_phase.content:
The high-fidelity designs leaned into typography and whitespace. We wanted the words to breathe.

Color was used sparingly—mostly to indicate interactive elements and turn status. The writing itself stayed neutral, letting each contributor's voice come through without visual interference.

Scroll through the reading experience below. Notice how the interface disappears when you're focused on the story.

images.caption: Clean reading experience with minimal UI
Writing interface with previous context visible

prototype.description: Experience the reading flow. Tap a story to open it, then scroll through contributions.

development.content:
This project was design-focused, but we kept implementation in mind throughout. Real-time collaboration features were scoped out early—they would have required backend complexity beyond our timeline.

Instead, we designed for asynchronous contribution. Turn-based writing actually fit the concept better: it gave each contributor time to think.
technical_decisions: Designed for asynchronous rather than real-time collaboration
Scoped out complex features like branching narratives
constraints: Real-time sync would require significant backend work
Needed to support multiple device sizes

feature_breakdown.intro: InkLink has three core modes of engagement. Explore them in the prototype below.

features.title: Public Story Chains
features.description: Open stories that anyone can contribute to. Writers join, add a passage, and pass the story forward.
features.why: Low barrier to entry. No commitment required—just jump in and write.

features.title: Private Writing Circles
features.description: Invite-only spaces for friends or writing groups. Turn order is set by the creator.
features.why: Some writers want collaboration without strangers. Private circles offer that control.

features.title: Timed Contributions
features.description: Optional time limits encourage momentum. If a turn expires, the next writer can step in.
features.why: Deadlines reduce overthinking. A 24-hour window is long enough to be fair, short enough to keep stories moving.

prototype.description: Start a new story, invite a friend, or join an existing chain. Follow the prompts to see each flow.

validation.content:
Testers described InkLink as 'fun'—which felt like a win.

The reduced pressure was noticeable. Users said they felt less precious about their contributions because they knew someone else would build on them.

One tester mentioned that the time limit actually helped: 'I stopped trying to make it perfect because I knew I only had a day.'

key_quotes.quote: I stopped trying to make it perfect because I knew I only had a day.

outcomes: Reduced pressure led to less perfectionism
Time limits helped rather than hurt the experience

what_i_learned.reflection: Limiting options (one clear CTA, timed turns) reduced friction instead of adding it.
The newspaper aesthetic was fun but counterproductive.
We cut more than we added—and the product got better.

next_steps.item: Add saved drafts so writers can step away mid-contribution
Improve accessibility with keyboard navigation and screen reader support
Design better onboarding for first-time users unfamiliar with chain writing

final_experience.intro:
The prototype below shows the complete InkLink experience—from discovering a story to making your first contribution.

Pay attention to how little stands between you and writing. That was intentional.

prototype.description: Click through the full flow. Find a story, read what others have written, and add your own passage.

case_studies.title: SideQuest
case_studies.subtitle: Turning boredom into micro-adventures
case_studies.summary: A web app that helps users discover small, low-commitment activities to break routine, reframing free time as an opportunity rather than a void to fill.

hook.content:
You have a free afternoon. Nothing planned. No obligations.

So you open your phone, scroll through options, and thirty minutes later you're still on the couch—paralyzed by choice, defaulting to nothing.

SideQuest was designed for that moment. Not to give you more options, but to give you one good one.

problem_framing.content:
Boredom isn't really about having nothing to do. It's about having too much to choose from and not enough motivation to pick.

Every app promises endless possibilities. But endless possibilities require endless decisions. And decisions are exhausting.

We wanted to flip that model. Instead of showing users everything they could do, we'd suggest one thing they might enjoy—and make it easy to say yes.

methods: Persona creation based on peer interviews
Competitive analysis of activity discovery apps
key_findings: Users want low-pressure activities that don't require planning
Choice overload causes hesitation and often leads to inaction
research_process.reflection: We assumed people wanted more options. They didn't. They wanted someone—or something—to just tell them what to do.

pivots.reason: Every filter we added made users less likely to act. Simplicity won.

pivot.reflection: We kept asking 'what if we add one more filter?' until we realized every filter was another reason not to act. The best feature was removing features.

weightLifted.title: From 5 filters to 1 button
weightLifted.caption: Every filter was another reason not to act. One button removed every excuse.

lofi_phase.content:
Our early wireframes had too many buttons.

Filters for location, duration, cost, category—all logical, all counterproductive. Users would hover over options without committing to any of them.

We stripped it back. One primary action: 'Give me a quest.' Everything else became optional.

images.caption: Initial designs with too many options

hifi_phase.content:
The high-fidelity designs introduced a mascot—a small character that guides users through the experience without feeling childish.

We used playful language ('quest' instead of 'activity') and warm colors to make the app feel inviting rather than utilitarian. The goal was to lower emotional resistance.

Tap the button below to receive a quest. Notice how little friction there is between wanting to do something and seeing a suggestion.

images.caption: The mascot welcomes users with a single clear action
Quest suggestions are simple and actionable
Just enough information to get started

prototype.description: Tap 'Give me a quest' and see what happens. Try refreshing for a different suggestion.

development.content:
I built this project as well as designed it, which meant every feature had to survive implementation.

Some ideas that looked great in Figma didn't survive contact with code. Others became simpler during development—and often better for it.

The constraint of being both designer and developer forced honesty about what was actually possible.
technical_decisions: Built with React for component reusability
Kept quest data local to avoid backend complexity
Prioritized fast load times and immediate interaction
constraints: Solo development meant limited feature scope
No backend meant static quest database
Needed to work well on both mobile and desktop

feature_breakdown.intro: SideQuest has three core elements. Explore each in the prototype below.

features.title: Quest Suggestions
features.description: Small, low-commitment activities framed as optional adventures. Each quest includes a title, brief description, and estimated time.
features.why: The word 'quest' makes mundane activities feel more interesting. Framing matters.

features.title: Friendly Guide
features.description: A small mascot character that appears throughout the experience, offering encouragement without being intrusive.
features.why: The mascot adds warmth and personality. It makes the app feel less like a tool and more like a companion.

features.title: Quick Start Flow
features.description: Users can get a quest in two taps. No account required, no preferences to set up first.
features.why: Every step between 'I'm bored' and 'here's something to do' is a chance for users to give up. We minimized steps.

prototype.description: Start from the home screen. Get a quest, save it for later, or ask for something different.

validation.content:
Users responded to the playfulness more than we expected.

The word 'quest' made people smile. The mascot got positive comments. The low-pressure framing worked—users said they felt more willing to try things because the stakes felt low.

One tester put it simply: 'It's like having a friend who always has ideas.'

key_quotes.quote: It's like having a friend who always has ideas.

what_i_learned.reflection: Getting users to act once is more valuable than giving them ten options.
Every element either builds confidence or creates doubt. There's no neutral.

what_i_learned.insight: Research, design, and code inform each other
what_i_learned.reflection: Being involved in all three made each one stronger.

next_steps.item: Add personalization based on past quest completions
Enable location-aware suggestions for nearby activities
Explore social features—sharing quests with friends

final_experience.intro:
The prototype below represents the full SideQuest experience—from opening the app to completing your first quest.

Notice how the design tries to get out of your way. The goal is momentum, not exploration.

prototype.description: Start fresh. Get a quest, see the details, and mark it complete. The whole flow takes under a minute.
